title: 108_hr4550
content: The Act is titled the "Safe, Efficient, Coordinated, Unified, Revitalized, Enhanced Visa Waiver Act" and requires electronic submission of biographical information by visa waiver participants. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish an electronic system for visa waiver program participants to submit biographical information before entering the US. The system must provide an electronic response on eligibility within 30 minutes. The electronic system established by the Secretary of Homeland Security allows visa waiver program participants to submit biographical information for eligibility determination within 30 minutes. Carriers and corporations must electronically inquire about an alien's eligibility before embarkation without a visa. The Secretary of Homeland Security will deploy an electronic system for visa waiver program participants to submit biographical information quickly. A fee will be charged to cover the system's costs, and consultation with private sector experts will be conducted during system development. SEC. 3. CHANGE TO REQUIREMENT FOR READERS AND SCANNERS AT PORTS OF ENTRY. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act requires the installation of equipment and software at all ports of entry into the United States for biometric comparison and authentication of visas, travel documents, and passports issued to aliens by October 26, 2005. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act mandates the installation of equipment and software at all US ports of entry for biometric comparison and authentication of passports issued under subsection (c)(1). The Technology Standard Implementation Deadline under the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act has been extended to 2005. Additionally, a Limited Good Faith Waiver provision has been introduced. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act has a Limited Good Faith Waiver provision allowing the Secretary of Homeland Security to grant up to 2 extensions for countries making progress towards meeting passport requirements. Each extension can be up to 6 months. The Secretary of Homeland Security considers factors like good faith efforts, program implementation, and pilot programs when determining a country's progress in meeting passport requirements under the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security will issue reports on countries' progress in meeting passport requirements under the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act. Initial report due by October 26, 2005, and final report by April 25, 2006. Section 303 of the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act is amended to replace "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security."
